questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that has a curb, your wheels should be turned away from the curb. When parking uphill on a street without a curb or when parking downhill, your wheels should be turned toward the curb or edge of the road.

questions.question: You should not use your horn:
questions.answerB: If you might hit another vehicle.
questions.answerC: Near blind pedestrians.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian, using your horn may be dangerous. Yield to the pedestrian and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You see pedestrians near the road. You should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn and maintain your speed.
questions.answerB: Speed up to clear the area quickly.
questions.answerC: Slow down and pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Watch for any pedestrian who may cross your path. If you see pedestrians near the road where you are driving, slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.

questions.question: What does a single dashed yellow line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Both lanes travel in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. A single dashed yellow line in the center of a road indicates that vehicles traveling in both directions are permitted to pass. Drivers may only begin a pass if they will not interfere with any oncoming traffic.

questions.question: What does a flashing yellow traffic light mean?
questions.answerB: Proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light indicates that you should drive with caution.

questions.question: You may exceed the speed limit to pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You must obey speed limits at all times. You may not exceed the speed limit to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Roundabout ahead.
questions.answerC: No U-turns.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This sign tells drivers that it is prohibited to make a U-turn.

questions.question: This sign indicates that:
questions.answerA: There is a steep hill ahead.
questions.answerB: No trucks are allowed on an upcoming hill.
questions.answerC: A logging road is ahead.
questions.answerD: There are trucks on an upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a steep hill or downgrade ahead.

questions.question: In which of the following ways can alcoholic beverages affect you?
questions.answerB: It gives you a feeling of false confidence.
questions.answerC: It impairs your thinking ability.
questions.explanation: Alcohol dulls the parts of your brain that control inhibition, judgment, and self-control. As a result, you may feel stimulated, lively, and a bit giddy or foolish after consuming alcohol. Alcohol also impairs your reaction time, coordination, and balance. Your vision and ability to judge distance suffers after alcohol consumption, making it difficult to react to your surroundings.

questions.question: If you stop along the road at night:
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights only.
questions.answerC: Use your headlights only.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams turned on.
questions.explanation: If you stop along the road at night, turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beam headlights turned on. Be sure that other road users will be able to clearly see your vehicle.

questions.question: To prevent hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Ensure that your tires are properly inflated.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed when driving in the rain.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, you should ensure that the tires on your vehicle have good tread depth and are inflated to the proper pressure. Reduce the speed of your vehicle when driving in the rain. Hydroplaning occurs most frequently at higher speeds.

questions.question: You may drive around or under a gate that is being lowered or raised at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: As long as an approaching train is not too close.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle can do so without damaging the gate.
questions.answerC: If you first look carefully in both directions.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights, lowered crossing gates, and/or bells at a railroad crossing mean that you must come to a complete stop. You must not go across the tracks until the lights and bells have stopped and the crossing gates are completely up. Do not drive around or under a gate that is moving up or down.

questions.question: When a school bus is stopped on the road ahead to load or unload children, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop until all the children have left the bus.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm is withdrawn.
questions.answerC: Change lanes, drive slowly, and pass the bus cautiously.
questions.explanation: When a school bus is stopped on the road ahead with its lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must come to a complete stop and wait to proceed until the lights have stopped flashing and the stop arm is withdrawn. Even after the bus begins to move again, do not proceed until you are sure there are no children crossing the road ahead of you.

questions.question: What does a single dashed white line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Lanes move in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic that are moving in the same direction. Dashed white lines may be crossed to pass or change lanes, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Drivers turning left must yield to:
questions.answerB: Oncoming cars.
questions.answerC: No one.
questions.explanation: Drivers turning left must yield to oncoming vehicles that are driving straight ahead. A turning driver may only proceed when they can safely turn without affecting oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid yellow arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular yellow traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Tells drivers that a green arrow is about to be shown.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow arrow has the same meaning as a yellow traffic light. When approaching a solid yellow arrow, you must reduce your speed and prepare for a red light.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No turning.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits U-turns. Do not make a U-turn where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Interstate driving requires drivers to:
questions.answerA: Have the ability to safely drive at increased speeds.
questions.answerB: Be constantly alert.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Safe use of the interstate demands drivers be constantly alert and capable of driving at high speeds.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection controlled by a flashing yellow light, you must:
questions.answerA: Wait for the green light before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.
questions.answerC: Stop before crossing the intersection.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light means drivers must slow down, be more aware, and proceed with caution. Be alert to crossing traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: Which of the following is a dangerous habit when driving in work zones?
questions.answerB: Failing to carefully watch for workers and moving equipment
questions.answerC: Both of the above
questions.explanation: When driving in a work zone, adjust your speed for the traffic conditions and don't follow other vehicles too closely. Be attentive to workers and machines in the work zone.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must not cross here.
questions.answerD: Be alert for construction workers on the road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. Drivers should be cautious when driving where pedestrians may be present.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection with a side road ahead.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle on a road with two lanes traveling in opposite directions, you should:
questions.answerA: Return to the driving lane when there's enough room between you and the vehicle you passed.
questions.answerB: Remain in the left lane if you intend to turn left.
questions.answerC: Return to the right side of the roadway immediately.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on a two-lane roadway, you must return to the right side of the roadway when there is enough room between you and the vehicle you have passed.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers that:
questions.answerA: The right lane is ending and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: The road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: There are upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that the number of lanes is reduced ahead and that traffic should merge left.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow arrow indicates that left turns are allowed in the direction of the arrow. However, the oncoming traffic has a green light and you must yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: You hit a parked vehicle and can't find the owner. What must you do?
questions.answerA: Call your insurance company when you get home.
questions.answerB: Wait for the owner to return.
questions.answerC: Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hit a parked vehicle or other property, you must leave a note with your name, phone number, and address securely attached to the vehicle or property that you hit.

questions.question: Crossbuck signs indicate:
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: No passing zones.
questions.explanation: Crossbuck signs tell drivers to yield to trains at a railroad crossing. Drivers should not try to outdrive a train.

questions.question: You are driving at night and another vehicle is approaching from the opposite direction. Your headlights:
questions.answerA: Should be on their high beam setting.
questions.answerB: Should be on their low beam setting.
questions.answerC: Should be off. Use your parking lights.
questions.answerD: May be on either their high or low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Do not use your high beam headlights when approaching or following another vehicle at night. Switch to the low beam setting to ensure the safety of everyone on the road.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal means that a ____ light will soon appear.
questions.answerB: Steady green
questions.answerC: Steady red
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light on a traffic signal indicates that a steady red light will soon appear.

questions.question: You have stopped for a train at a railroad crossing. After the train passes, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait for signal lights to stop flashing.
questions.answerB: Look for a second train.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Even after a train passes, watch out for a second train approaching on any track. Do not proceed until all gates have been lifted and all warning signals have stopped flashing.

questions.question: What does a lane control signal displaying a green arrow above a reversible lane indicate?
questions.answerA: The signal is about to change to a red X.
questions.answerB: Drivers should not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: Drivers may use this lane only to make a left turn.
questions.answerD: Drivers may drive normally in this lane.
questions.explanation: Lane control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. When a lane control signal contains a green arrow, drivers may drive normally in the indicated lane.

questions.question: At dusk or on overcast days, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive using your parking lights.
questions.answerC: Not turn on any vehicle lights.
questions.explanation: At dusk or on overcast days, you must turn on your headlights. Dim your lights to their low beam setting when within 1,000 feet of an approaching vehicle and when within 500 feet of a vehicle that you are following. When driving in poor weather, always use your low beams.

questions.question: Should you always drive more slowly than other traffic?
questions.answerA: No, you can block traffic when you drive too slowly.
questions.answerB: Yes, it is a good defensive driving technique.
questions.answerC: Yes, it is always safer than driving faster than other traffic.
questions.explanation: You must drive more slowly than usual when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. However, if you block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic by driving too slowly, you may be cited.

questions.question: The center of the roadway is marked with one solid yellow line and one broken yellow line. If the broken yellow line is directly next to your traffic lane, it means:
questions.answerA: You are not allowed to pass in this area.
questions.answerB: You are in a passing zone and it is safe for you to pass other vehicles on the left if no oncoming traffic is present.
questions.answerC: You are only allowed to make right turns in this area.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road, passing is permitted from the side of the road next to the broken line.

questions.question: When driving on gravel or dirt roads:
questions.answerA: Your tires grip the road better than when you are driving on pavement.
questions.answerB: Your tires do not have as much traction as they do on pavement, so you must slow down.
questions.answerC: Visibility is better than on pavement.
questions.explanation: Your tires do not have as much traction on loose gravel and dirt roads as they do on concrete and asphalt roads. When driving on gravel or dirt, you must slow down. It will take you much longer to stop and it is much easier to skid when turning.

questions.question: When should you yield your legal right-of-way?
questions.answerB: Whenever it helps prevent collisions.
questions.answerC: Never. It confuses other drivers.
questions.explanation: Never assume other drivers will give you the right-of-way. Yield your right-of-way whenever it helps prevent collisions.

questions.question: Highways and roads freeze before ramps and bridges.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Ramps and bridges are suspended in the air, causing them to become icy very quickly in cold weather. Drive with extra caution when crossing a bridge in freezing temperatures.

questions.question: If you are driving and a tire suddenly goes flat, you should:
questions.answerA: Rapidly pump the brake pedal several times.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and not brake.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake pedal as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: If a tire blows out or suddenly goes flat while you are driving, grip the steering wheel firmly and keep the vehicle aiming straight. Take your foot off the accelerator and do not brake. Allow the vehicle to slow by itself and use the brakes gently, but only if necessary. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you are driving near a large commercial vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the large vehicle closely to reduce wind drag on your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving beside it for long stretches of time.
questions.answerC: Drive on its right side when on curves and hills.
questions.explanation: Because large commercial vehicles have large blind spots on each side, you should avoid driving beside them for long periods of time.

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Tow-away zone.
questions.answerC: Steep downgrade.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be cautious when driving under conditions that may cause the roadway to become wet and slippery.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you:
questions.answerA: Must yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Must yield to vehicles only on your right.
questions.answerC: Should slow down but never stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a yield sign, drivers must give the right-of-way to traffic already in the lanes that they intend to enter or cross. Drivers should be prepared to stop when approaching a yield sign but may continue without stopping if there is no conflicting traffic.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: The term “distracted driving” refers to driving while anything takes your eyes, hands, or mind away from the task at hand. Distracted driving is the most common contributing factor to reported traffic collisions. Distractions of any sort cause drivers to miss key visual and audio cues needed to avoid a crash.

questions.question: An approaching driver fails to dim their high beam headlights. Where should you look?
questions.answerA: At the wheels of the approaching vehicle.
questions.answerB: Toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Toward the left side of the road.
questions.answerD: Straight down the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: If an approaching driver fails to dim their high beams, glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course until the other vehicle has passed.

questions.question: You may drink alcoholic beverages in a vehicle on a public highway:
questions.answerA: As long as you aren't driving.
questions.answerB: If you are riding in the back seat.
questions.answerC: If you are riding in the back of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: It is against the law to consume or possess any alcoholic beverage while on a public road or sidewalk. Additionally, storing an open alcoholic beverage container in an area of a motor vehicle normally occupied by the driver or passenger is prohibited on any public road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No U-turns.
questions.answerC: No exit.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: There are oncoming vehicles to your left and a row of parked vehicles to your right. You should steer:
questions.answerA: Closer to the oncoming vehicles than the parked vehicles.
questions.answerB: Closer to the parked vehicles than the oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerC: A middle course between the oncoming and parked vehicles.
questions.explanation: If there are oncoming vehicles to your left and a row of parked vehicles to your right, the best thing to do is to split the difference. Steer a middle course between the oncoming cars and the parked cars.

questions.question: If a road is slippery, maintain a following distance that is:
questions.answerB: Farther from the car ahead than normal.
questions.answerC: Closer to the car ahead than normal.
questions.explanation: You need a longer distance to stop your vehicle on a slippery road than you do on a dry road. Maintain an increased following distance when driving on slippery roads.

questions.question: To pass on a two-lane road, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn as you pass.
questions.answerB: Flash your headlights as you pass.
questions.answerC: Judge the distance to any oncoming vehicles.
questions.explanation: It can be hard to judge the speed of oncoming vehicles. They do not always seem to be coming as fast as they really are. Always be sure you can safely change lanes when passing on a two-lane street. If you are not sure of an oncoming vehicle's speed, wait to pass until the oncoming vehicle has passed and you are sure there is enough space for you to change lanes safely.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: A steep grade is ahead.
questions.answerC: The overpass ahead has a low clearance.
questions.answerD: Two lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are about to merge.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. Do not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height indicated (in this case, 13 feet, 6 inches).

questions.question: To enter a freeway:
questions.answerA: Signal, yield to existing traffic, and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving.
questions.answerB: Signal and enter the freeway. Freeway traffic must yield.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly so you can check traffic.
questions.answerD: Always come to a complete stop first.
questions.explanation: When merging into traffic, you should signal and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving. Always yield to other traffic when entering a roadway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Fines double in a work zone.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching an area with low clearance.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: The road ahead curves left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves right, then left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left. You should slow down to be able to negotiate these curves safely.

questions.question: Motorists are not required to yield to pedestrians if they are walking against the traffic light.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You must always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians. Be aware of the possibility that pedestrians may misjudge traffic signals and cross against a light.

questions.question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to.
questions.answerB: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn.
questions.answerC: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb.
questions.explanation: If you try to insert your vehicle between a turning truck or bus and a curb, you may suffer a serious crash. To avoid a collision, do not turn until the truck or bus has completed its turn.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You can travel in either direction in this lane.
questions.answerB: There is two-way traffic.
questions.answerC: You are approaching a divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A green arrow:
questions.answerA: Is used only on one-way streets.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic must turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: Means that you may proceed, but only if the green arrow is accompanied by a circular green light.
questions.answerD: Points the way to an airport.
questions.explanation: A green arrow has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic in the indicated lane must turn in the direction shown by the arrow.

questions.question: You notice a vehicle defect which may affect the safe operation of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Correct the defect as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Correct the defect when you can afford it.
questions.answerC: Drive the vehicle at slower speeds.
questions.explanation: Any defect that may affect the safe operation of a vehicle should be corrected as soon as possible. Defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: You must yield to a pedestrian using a white cane or guide dog:
questions.answerA: Only when the guide dog is leading the person across the street.
questions.answerB: At all times.
questions.answerC: Only if a crossing guard is present.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians who use guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

questions.question: You experience an incident at work that has left you feeling angry. When you get to your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Play the radio loudly so you won’t think about it.
questions.answerB: Drive fast on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.answerC: Take a few minutes to cool off before you begin your drive home.
questions.answerD: Stop at your favorite bar and have a few drinks before driving home.
questions.explanation: Persons who are upset, angry, or otherwise distracted by their emotions should take time to cool off before driving a car. Taking out frustrations or anger while driving is exercising very poor judgment and is very dangerous to both the driver and others on the road.

questions.question: What does a lane control signal displaying a flashing yellow X above a reversible lane indicate?
questions.answerA: The signal is about to change to a red X.
questions.answerB: The signal is about to change to a green arrow.
questions.answerC: Drivers may use this lane only to turn.
questions.answerD: Drivers may drive slowly in this lane.
questions.explanation: Lane control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. When a lane control signal contains a flashing yellow X, drivers may only use the indicated lane to complete a left turn.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: When you intend to back up, you should always check behind your car for bikes, tricycles, and small children before entering the car.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When you intend to back up, always check behind your car for bikes, tricycles, and small children before you get into your car. This is an especially important practice for drivers of larger vehicles, such as vans and trucks.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: In a curve or on a hill because the chance is small that another vehicle is coming.
questions.answerB: By using the shoulder of the highway.
questions.answerC: If your lane is next to a solid yellow line and the passing lane is clear ahead.
questions.explanation: You may not pass another vehicle on a hill or in a curve because you cannot see oncoming traffic and may cause a collision. Never pass another vehicle by driving onto the shoulder of a highway. Passing another vehicle by driving over a solid yellow line is prohibited.

questions.question: You should allow an extra cushion of space:
questions.answerB: When following a driver who cannot see the rear of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: When following a small passenger car.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, or any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline indicates that:
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline next to your side of the road indicates that traffic may cross the centerline to pass from your side of the road.

questions.question: Car drivers should know that large trucks:
questions.answerB: Can stop more quickly than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Do not need more room to maneuver than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: A large truck has large blind spots to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle. Avoid lingering in these areas. Because of their larger size and weight, trucks require more room to maneuver and stop than passenger vehicles.

questions.question: You must yield to children playing in the streets.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You are responsible for driving with extreme caution where children are present. Slow down near schools and playgrounds and in residential areas.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: You must turn left ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not enter.
questions.explanation: This signs warns that a four-way intersection is ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must turn right.
questions.answerC: Watch for traffic on your right.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits right turns. You cannot make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: When should you drive in a reversible lane controlled by a signal showing a red X?
questions.answerA: When there is no visible oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: When you are passing the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Never.
questions.explanation: Lane control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. Never drive in a lane marked with a red X.

questions.question: Backing your vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Dangerous if you have a helper.
questions.answerC: Only dangerous in large vehicles.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is hard to see behind your vehicle. Use extra caution when backing up.

questions.question: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means:
questions.answerA: Passing on the left is permitted from either direction.
questions.answerB: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken line.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the solid line.
questions.answerD: Passing is not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means that passing is allowed from the lane on the side next to the broken line.

questions.question: If you find yourself in a skid:
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.answerC: Brake abruptly.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, do not use the brakes. Braking could make the skid worse.

questions.question: If you see this sign above your lane, you:
questions.answerB: May either continue through the interchange or exit the freeway from your current lane.
questions.answerC: May stay in your lane and continue through the interchange.
questions.answerD: Must exit the freeway, if you stay in your current lane.
questions.explanation: If a yellow panel with the message "Exit only" is on a highway sign, the lane below the sign will not continue through the interchange. Instead, the lane will go off of the roadway to form a ramp. If you are in a lane directly under an "Exit only" sign, you may change lanes to move through the interchange or you must exit the highway.

questions.question: What is the only way to reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Allow your body time to get rid of the alcohol.
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is to not drink alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: You enter a designated turn lane to make a left turn at an upcoming intersection. There is oncoming traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move to the left of the center lane.
questions.answerB: Signal before you arrive at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Turn your front wheels to the left to be prepared to turn.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should always begin signaling about 100 feet before the turn. You should keep your front wheels aiming straight ahead until it is safe to start your turn. This ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic if another vehicle hits you from behind.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from a parking area or alley.
questions.explanation: Your turn signals should always be used when you make any movement to the left or right. You should use your signal when pulling into traffic from a curbside parking space, moving into a new lane, or passing another vehicle.

questions.question: It is more dangerous to drive at night than during the day because:
questions.answerA: You cannot see as far ahead at night.
questions.answerB: The road is always more slippery at night.
questions.answerC: Your reaction time is slower at night.
questions.explanation: With decreased visibility and the glare of oncoming headlights, you cannot see as far ahead at night as you can during the day. Always use headlights and exercise caution when driving in the dark.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill where there is no curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels toward the edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels facing straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that does not have a curb, your front wheels should be turned to the right (toward the edge of the road). This will ensure that the vehicle will roll off of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerB: School crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.explanation: A downward-facing triangular sign is always a yield sign. Drivers must be prepared to slow down or stop when approaching a yield sign.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: The highway ahead curves only to the right.
questions.answerB: The highway ahead turns sharply to the right.
questions.answerC: The highway ahead curves to the right and then to the left.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead curves to the left and then to the right.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerB: Privilege, not a right.
questions.answerC: Requirement.
questions.explanation: Holding a driver license is not a right. It is a privilege that must be earned and maintained.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: The road ahead turns sharply left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves to the left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: Alcohol:
questions.answerB: Puts you to sleep.
questions.answerC: Wakes you up.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant drug that slows the activity of the brain and reduces the skills that you need for safe driving. Drinking alcohol results in slowed reaction time and impaired judgment.

questions.question: In traffic moving at 50 to 55 mph, you are least likely to have an accident if you:
questions.answerA: Drive a few miles per hour faster than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Stay within that speed range.
questions.answerC: Drive a few miles per hour slower than most other vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should adjust your speed to travel smoothly with the other traffic on a roadway (provided that the other traffic is driving within the posted speed limits). Remember that vehicles moving in the same direction at the same speed cannot hit each other. Crashes involving multiple vehicles often happen when some vehicles are traveling at different speeds than others.

questions.question: When driving in a construction zone:
questions.answerB: Expect the unexpected.
questions.answerC: Expect construction workers to yield to motorists.
questions.explanation: You may encounter unexpected conditions in a construction zone. For the safety of yourself, other drivers, and construction workers, drive with extraordinary caution.

questions.question: When passing another car, you have enough space to return to the driving lane:
questions.answerA: If the other driver signals for you to re-enter the lane.
questions.answerB: If you look over your shoulder and see the passed car behind you.
questions.answerC: If you can see both of the passed vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to the driving lane when completing a pass, be sure there is a safe gap between your vehicle and the passed vehicle. When you can see both headlights of the vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: How fast you drive does not affect the distance your vehicle travels after you brake to come to a stop.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: When driving in high-speed traffic, it is extremely important to stay well behind the vehicle in front of you. As your speed increases, the distance it will take for your vehicle to stop also increases.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: What should you do when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Look for a train station ahead.
questions.answerB: Signal before going any further.
questions.answerC: Slow down and yield to trains.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Ease up on the gas pedal.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as possible.
questions.answerC: Turn off the ignition.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, release the accelerator or brake pedal to regain vehicle balance. Steer in the direction of the skid to regain control of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you need to drive in foggy weather:
questions.answerA: Turn on your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights.
questions.answerC: It is okay to drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerD: Do not drive at a speed above 10 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: You are required to use your headlights during the day when visibility is reduced to 500 feet or less. When you first turn on your headlights, be sure they are adjusted to the low beam setting. Using high beams in fog or rain will cause the light to reflect back into your eyes, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: Under normal weather and traffic conditions, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.explanation: The more distance between your vehicle and others, the more time you will have to react if another driver makes a mistake. Keep a minimum following distance of three seconds under normal weather and traffic conditions. Increase your following distance when driving under unusual weather or traffic conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane closed ahead.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This warning sign indicates that a traffic signal is ahead and drivers should prepare to react to a yellow or red light.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for people crossing your path.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Work zone ahead.
questions.explanation: This orange warning sign tells drivers that an area of roadwork is upcoming. When traveling through a work zone, stay alert for temporary traffic control devices.

questions.question: If you stop at a railroad crossing with more than one track:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until you have a clear view of all tracks.
questions.answerB: Stop on the first railroad track and watch for another train.
questions.answerC: Go through as soon as the train passes.
questions.answerD: Go through when one of the tracks is free.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing with more than one track, do not start moving as soon as a train passes. Wait until you have a clear view down all tracks before you start across. Even where there is only one track, do not start across immediately after a train passes; check again for another train that may be approaching.

questions.question: What are the colors of signs that tell you the distance to the next exit on a highway?
questions.answerB: Black with white letters
questions.answerC: Red with white letters
questions.explanation: Signs providing information about destinations are green with white letters or symbols.

questions.question: Which of the following commonly causes traffic accidents?
questions.answerB: Excessive speed under the driving conditions
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles too closely
questions.explanation: Driving too fast for conditions is a major cause of motor vehicle crashes. Being inattentive to surroundings can cause a driver to collide with other vehicles. Most rear-end collisions are caused by drivers following other vehicles too closely.

questions.question: Do not pass:
questions.answerB: When school bus lights are flashing.
questions.answerC: When approaching an intersection.
questions.explanation: You should never pass if there is an oncoming vehicle in the passing lane, if your view is blocked by a curve or hill, at an intersection, before or on a railroad crossing or bridge, or in any other no passing zone. Unless you are on the opposite side of a multilane roadway with a median or shared center turn lane, you may not pass a stopped school bus that has its flashing red lights activated.

questions.question: If traffic ahead is blocking an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your horn to get traffic to move.
questions.answerB: Drive closely to the car ahead of you, just in case the light turns red.
questions.answerC: Wait to enter the intersection until you can cross the intersection entirely.
questions.explanation: Drivers may not enter an intersection unless they can get through it without having to stop. You should wait until traffic ahead clears so that you are not blocking the intersection.

questions.question: When driving, you should look ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 45 seconds
questions.answerC: 15 to 20 seconds
questions.explanation: Watch 15 to 20 seconds ahead of your vehicle for cars braking, turning, or entering and exiting the road. This helps to prevent sudden stops and turns.

questions.question: When may you proceed through an intersection that has a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk?
questions.answerA: After slowing down to verify that there is no cross traffic
questions.answerB: After coming to a complete stop and verifying that it is safe to proceed
questions.answerC: After you have stopped at least 20 feet prior to the intersection
questions.answerD: After slowing down to a speed of 10 mph
questions.explanation: Stop before the stop line or crosswalk at any intersection that is controlled by a stop sign. If there is a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: What is the appropriate action to take when approaching a railroad crossing that does not have signals to direct traffic?
questions.answerA: Always bring the car to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerC: All railroad crossings have signals so you will never encounter this situation.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to get across the tracks quickly.
questions.explanation: When approaching an unmarked railroad crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Before you cross, be sure that no trains are approaching from either direction on any track. If you see or hear a train coming, stop at a safe distance from the nearest track and wait to proceed until after the train passes.

questions.question: You want to park uphill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which direction do you turn your front wheels?
questions.answerB: Right, toward the side of the road
questions.answerC: Left, toward the center of the road
questions.explanation: When parking either uphill or downhill on a road that has no curb, you should turn your wheels so that the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: The road ahead curves left then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves right then left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the upcoming road will curve right, followed by a curve to the left. Drivers should adjust their speed to safely continue on the road.

questions.question: A reflective orange triangle on the back of a vehicle indicates that:
questions.answerB: It is an ambulance.
questions.answerC: It is a school bus.
questions.explanation: A reflective orange triangle on the rear of a vehicle means the vehicle is traveling at speeds slower than 25 mph. You may see this decal on construction equipment, farm vehicles, and horse-drawn wagons or carriages.

questions.question: The presence of double solid yellow lines means you may pass another vehicle from either direction.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line means that it is prohibited for vehicles traveling in either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: Blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on each of the following, except:
questions.answerB: How much you drink.
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks.
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. It is not affected by the type of alcoholic beverages you drink, your level of physical fitness, or how well you can "hold your liquor."

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: One-way traffic.
questions.answerC: Limited parking.
questions.explanation: Circular traffic signs indicate upcoming railroad crossings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching a railroad crossing and should be looking for signs of an oncoming train.

questions.question: When driving in fog, rain, or snow, use:
questions.answerB: High beams.
questions.answerC: Fog lights only.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used in fog, rain, and snow. The light from high beams will reflect back to the driver under these weather conditions, causing a glare that will make it difficult to see ahead.

questions.question: When passing an emergency vehicle stopped on the right side of the road, drivers should:
questions.answerB: Vacate the lane closest to the emergency vehicle or slow down.
questions.answerC: Ask the emergency worker if they need help.
questions.answerD: Move to the lane closest to the emergency vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are driving past an emergency vehicle parked on the right side of the road, you must vacate the lane closest to the stationary emergency vehicle. If you cannot move over safely, you must slow down.

questions.question: What should you do when an emergency vehicle is approaching while displaying flashing red or blue lights?
questions.answerA: See if you can reach your destination before the emergency vehicle catches up to you.
questions.answerB: Continue driving but try to stay out of its way.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road and come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Stop in the middle of an intersection.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to all emergency vehicles using a siren, air horn, and/or flashing red, blue, or white lights. Where possible, you must pull over to the right edge of the road. If you are in an intersection, drive through the intersection before you pull over.

questions.question: Temporary signs used in construction and maintenance work areas:
questions.answerA: Have a red background with green writing.
questions.answerB: Have an orange background with black writing.
questions.answerC: Have a yellow background with blue writing.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have orange backgrounds with black writing and/or symbols.

questions.question: A curb painted red means:
questions.answerB: The area is reserved for picking up or dropping off passengers.
questions.answerC: No parking, standing, or stopping.
questions.explanation: You may not stop, stand, or park at a red-painted curb.

questions.question: You are required to signal every time you pull away from a curb.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You must use the proper turn signal any time you pull away from a curb.

questions.question: If a vehicle starts to skid on water, the driver should quickly apply the brakes.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: If a vehicle skids while hydroplaning, the driver should try to regain control of the vehicle. If that is not possible, the driver should release the accelerator and ride out the skid. The driver should not immediately apply the brakes.

questions.question: What should you do when you are going to enter a roadway from a private road?
questions.answerA: Blow your horn to warn cars you are entering the roadway.
questions.answerB: Stop with part of your car on the roadway to alert other drivers.
questions.answerC: Drive out fast to merge smoothly with the traffic.
questions.answerD: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a roadway from a driveway or private road, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and traffic on the roadway.

questions.question: When driving on slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive as you would on dry roads.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: On slippery roads, you should increase your following distance. It may take more time to stop your vehicle than it would under normal conditions.

questions.question: When entering an interstate highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop, check for cars, and enter when safe.
questions.answerB: Check for cars and reduce your speed to 25 mph before entering the traffic lane.
questions.answerC: Check for cars, increase your speed to match the flow of traffic, and merge when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: Rather than stopping (as you would when entering other roads), you must use the merging or acceleration lane to speed up and smoothly merge with fast-moving traffic already on the interstate.

questions.question: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest you can drive in an area.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal driving speed in an area, under ideal conditions. You must reduce your speed when conditions require it, such as when the roadway is slippery or when it is difficult to see clearly down the road.

questions.question: It is unlawful for a car to try to share a lane with a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators have the right to use a complete traffic lane. Two motorcyclists may share a lane, but a car should never try to share a lane with a motorcycle.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit on a four-lane divided highway is:
questions.answerB: 55 mph.
questions.answerC: 70 mph.
questions.explanation: When driving on a four-lane divided highway, the speed limit is 70 miles per hour. If a different speed limit is posted, follow the posted speed limit.

questions.question: Don’t follow other cars too closely because:
questions.answerA: You may not see the road between the cars.
questions.answerB: You may not have time to stop if the vehicle in front of you slows or stops suddenly.
questions.answerC: You may not see the vehicle's turn signals.
questions.answerD: You may not see the other vehicle’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: If you follow too closely and the vehicle in front of you slows or stops suddenly, you may not have enough time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Take your foot of the gas.
questions.answerB: Do not immediately use your brakes.
questions.answerC: Gradually slow down and pull off the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, take your foot off the gas pedal and do not immediately apply the brakes. Gradually slow down before gently applying the brakes and pulling off the side of the road.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the road. To prevent hydroplaning in wet weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is caused by driving too fast on a wet road. Slow down when driving on wet pavement to prevent hydroplaning.

questions.question: Driving while being distracted by any activity:
questions.answerB: Usually causes the driver to react more slowly to hazards.
questions.answerC: Usually causes the driver to drive faster.
questions.answerD: Is only dangerous for young drivers.
questions.explanation: Distractions cause drivers to react more slowly to traffic and hazards on the roadway. Distracted driving is never safe.

questions.question: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver:
questions.answerB: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Tailgate the driver in front of you.
questions.explanation: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver, concentrate on driving and don't take the actions of other drivers personally. Be realistic about your travel time, drive within posted speed limits, and be forgiving of other drivers using the roadway.

questions.question: In bad weather, increase your following distance to:
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Two seconds.
questions.explanation: The more distance between your vehicle and others, the more time you will have to react if another driver makes a mistake. Keep a minimum following distance of four seconds when driving under poor weather and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Vehicle stopping distances never depend on:
questions.answerB: The time of day.
questions.answerC: The condition of your vehicle's brakes.
questions.answerD: The condition and type of your vehicle's tires.
questions.explanation: The distance that a vehicle needs to stop depends on the motorist's reaction time, weather and visibility conditions, the vehicle's weight, the conditions of the vehicle's brakes, the condition and type of the vehicle's tires, roadway conditions, and speed.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the surface of the road. To prevent hydroplaning in rainy weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, you should lower your speed to reduce the risk of hydroplaning. Driving too fast may cause your tires to ride up on the water and lose contact with the surface of the road, making it very difficult to control your vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow arrow indicates that a red arrow is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: You should be cautious when passing a bicycle because:
questions.answerA: You are moving faster than the bicycle.
questions.answerB: The bicycle always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic may not see you pull out to pass the bicycle.
questions.answerD: The cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road.
questions.explanation: You should always be cautious when passing a bicycle because the cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road. Always be particularly careful when driving near bicyclists.

questions.question: Defensive driving is:
questions.answerB: Using safe driving strategies to prevent crashes.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than not driving defensively.
questions.explanation: Defensive driving is using safe driving strategies to prevent crashes. This means that you alter your driving to fit the weather conditions, the way you feel, and the actions of other drivers, bicyclists, and pedestrians.

questions.question: You may drive across a dashed white line:
questions.answerB: Only during daylight hours.
questions.answerC: When it is safe to change lanes.
questions.explanation: Traffic lanes moving in the same direction are separated by broken white lines. You may cross over dashed lines to pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A work zone:
questions.answerB: Is marked with black and white signs.
questions.answerC: Does not require a driver to slow down and pay extra attention.
questions.explanation: Work zones are often stationary, but they may also be present in the form of moving vehicles striping lines, mowing, or removing snow. Work zones are marked by orange signs with black lettering or symbols. Slow down and pay extra attention when approaching or driving through a work zone.

questions.question: If you see a pedestrian using a guide dog or carrying a white cane:
questions.answerA: The pedestrian must yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to let them know you are there.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian with a guide dog or a white cane.

questions.question: You have allowed the wheels of your vehicle to run off the edge of the pavement. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels slightly to the left to edge the car back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes and turn the front wheels sharply to the left.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle leaves the roadway, hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes. Wait until your speed has reduced, check the traffic, and look for a place to safely return to the roadway by merging back into traffic. Overcompensating by jerking the wheel to return to the roadway can cause you to lose control of your vehicle or may cause your car to go into other lanes of traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow and black. This sign tells drivers that a lane is ending and that they should prepare to allow traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: Fines for moving traffic violations in construction and maintenance zones are:
questions.answerB: Doubled.
questions.answerC: Non-existent.
questions.explanation: In Oklahoma, fines for all traffic violations occurring in a construction or maintenance zone are doubled if workers are present and warning signs are present in advance of the work zone.

questions.question: You may exceed the speed limit to pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You must obey speed limits at all times. You may not exceed the speed limit to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerB: Open your window.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for:
questions.answerA: The increased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerB: The decreased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerC: The decreased noise of larger vehicles.
questions.answerD: The increased speed of larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for the increased stopping distance required by the large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should remain in locations where they can be seen by the driver of the large vehicle and where their view of traffic is not blocked by the vehicle.

questions.question: When you drive through an area where children are playing, you should expect them:
questions.answerA: To know when it is safe to cross the street.
questions.answerB: To stop at the curb before crossing the street.
questions.answerC: To run out in front of you without looking.
questions.answerD: Not to cross the street unless they are with an adult.
questions.explanation: You should always reduce your speed and use extra caution when children are in the vicinity. They may fail to understand the danger and may run out in front of you without looking.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, a driver should wait until the entire car they've just passed is visible in the rearview mirror before changing back into the right-hand lane.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until the entire vehicle you've just passed is visible in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: Before turning left, it is important to:
questions.answerB: Yield to oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerC: Swing to the right side of your lane.
questions.answerD: Wait until oncoming traffic has a red light.
questions.explanation: When turning left at a traffic signal, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You are approaching a green traffic light and traffic is blocking the intersection. What is the best thing to do?
questions.answerA: Partially enter the intersection to establish your right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Don't enter the intersection until you can get completely across.
questions.answerC: Continue into the intersection and wait for traffic to clear.
questions.explanation: Even if your light is green, you must not enter an intersection unless you can get completely through the intersection before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: Double solid yellow line markings down the center of a road indicate that passing is:
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double yellow centerline means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: When entering the interstate, check for a gap in traffic in the nearest lane, adjust your speed to match traffic, signal, and:
questions.answerA: Expect traffic to allow you to proceed into the lane, since you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Merge carefully into the gap.
questions.answerC: Wait for the lane to clear before merging.
questions.explanation: Before merging into interstate traffic, you should identify a gap, accelerate to the speed of traffic, and signal. Merge into the gap when it is safe to do so. Be alert to other traffic and do not expect other drivers to clear the lane.

questions.question: If a traffic light shows both a red light and a green arrow, a driver may not turn in the direction of the arrow until the red light has changed.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: After yielding the right-of-way to traffic within an intersection or crosswalk, a driver may go in the direction a green arrow is pointing, regardless of other lights present.

questions.question: When involved in a collision, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the injured as far away from the road as possible.
questions.answerB: Move the injured to their desired location.
questions.answerC: Insist the injured are fine without immediate medical attention.
questions.answerD: Avoid moving the injured yourself unless absolutely necessary.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to move injured persons. You should avoid moving the injured unless it is absolutely necessary to remove them from areas threatened by fire or other dangers common to a crash scene. Keep the injured lying or sitting down until competent medical aid arrives.

questions.question: Before changing lanes or attempting to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your blind spots and mirrors.
questions.answerB: Signal your intention before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Every time you want to change lanes or otherwise move your vehicle to the right or left, signal to alert other drivers to your intentions. Always check your mirrors and turn your head to check your blind spot before attempting any lateral move.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Merging traffic.
questions.answerC: Steep hill ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid collisions and brake damage.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: What is an important step in turning?
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Always move to the left lane.
questions.explanation: When turning, you should look to the rear and both sides of your vehicle to ensure it is safe to proceed before making the turn. Adjust your speed to safely complete the turn.

questions.question: Signs that are colored orange are:
questions.answerB: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerC: School zone signs.
questions.explanation: Highway work zones are established according to the type of work underway along the roadway. Signs in work areas are typically diamond-shaped, orange, have black letters or symbols, and serve as a warning that people are working on or near the highway.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the tracks before the gate is lowered.
questions.answerC: Try to drive around a lowered gate.
questions.answerD: Not pay attention to how many tracks there are to cross.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks, you should look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop for trains or other vehicles that may be using the rails.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the thinking of defensive drivers?
questions.answerA: They know other drivers will do the right thing.
questions.answerB: They consider what other drivers might do and are prepared to react.
questions.answerC: They expect no breaks and give none.
questions.explanation: Driving defensively means anticipating potential errors made by others and preparing to compensate for their mistakes.

questions.question: Every motor vehicle in the state of Oklahoma is required to be covered by liability insurance.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Oklahoma law requires every owner and operator of a motor vehicle to maintain motor vehicle liability insurance. Every vehicle you operate must be insured, even if you are not the owner.

questions.question: If the driver of an oncoming vehicle fails to dim their headlights:
questions.answerA: Look toward the center of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their headlights, look toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course. Do not try to retaliate by keeping your bright lights on.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lines painted down the middle of the road mean:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerD: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines in the center of the road mean that passing is not allowed from either direction. You may not cross the lines unless you are making a left turn or passing pedestrians, bicyclists, and riders of scooters or skateboards when the opposite lane is clear and you can pass safely.

questions.question: Before turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn the wheel.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: To complete a turn safely, you should activate your turn signal three to four seconds before your turn.

questions.question: The maximum posted speed limit should be driven only:
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: Under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. It is safest to drive at the same speed as surrounding traffic, up to the maximum speed limit. Maintaining a safe speed at all times is a responsibility shared by all motorists.

questions.question: When two vehicles arrive to an intersection at the same time, which one has the right-of-way when no signs or signals indicate rules?
questions.answerA: The car approaching from the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car approaching from the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car in which the driver sounds his horn first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: The car that is traveling the fastest has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: At an intersection of two similar roads without a traffic control device, a driver must yield to a vehicle approaching from the right.

questions.question: When driving past a vehicle that has just stopped in a parked position on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume that the driver will open the car door as you approach.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerD: Assume that the driver will wait for you to pass before opening the door.
questions.explanation: When passing a vehicle that has just parked parallel to the road, you should assume the driver will open the door as you approach. Use extra caution when driving near parked vehicles.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with airbags, the safest place for children age 12 and under to ride is in:
questions.answerB: The back seat.
questions.answerC: The bed of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: While airbags provide supplemental protection for adults in the event of a crash, they pose a severe safety risk for children. Anyone age 12 or under should sit in the back seat of a vehicle with airbags.

questions.question: If you plan to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not assume the other driver will make space for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Assume the other driver will maintain a constant speed.
questions.explanation: Even when you signal, you should not assume that the space you want to occupy is free or that other drivers will give you the right-of-way.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit on country roads is:
questions.answerB: 35 mph.
questions.answerC: 45 mph.
questions.explanation: When driving on a country road, the speed limit is 55 miles per hour. If a different speed limit is posted, follow the posted speed limit.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended upward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended upward, they are indicating that they intend to turn right. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking downhill, turn your front wheels toward the curb or edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road without a curb, turn your wheels toward the edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, you must turn your front wheels away from the curb.

questions.question: You come to an intersection that is blocked by other traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Go slowly until the traffic ahead moves.
questions.answerB: Get as close as possible to the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Stay out of the intersection until you can pass through.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn to make the cars move up.
questions.explanation: You cannot enter an intersection if traffic is backed up on the other side and you cannot get completely through the intersection. Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection.

questions.question: Alcohol in any concentration is:
questions.answerB: A depressant.
questions.answerC: Neither of the above.
