questions.explanation: Alcohol, in any concentration, is a depressant. It slows all nerve impulses and bodily functions, resulting in a lessening of inhibitions and negatively affecting a consumer's ability to concentrate and stay alert.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Upcoming change in direction.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided red sign means "stop."

questions.question: If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Not cross the tracks until the train has completely passed.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks at your own risk.
questions.answerD: Find an alternative route across tracks.
questions.explanation: You should look and listen for trains before crossing any railroad tracks. If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you cannot go across the tracks. This is true even if they have no signals or the signals are not working.

questions.question: Which is the most common cause of traffic crashes?
questions.answerB: Human error
questions.answerC: Bad weather
questions.explanation: Crashes often occur when one driver does not see another vehicle or when a driver does something unexpected. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent traffic crashes.

questions.question: Because driving involves some risk, it is wise to continually improve your driving and observation skills.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Driving can become unsafe if drivers believe they have nothing to improve. For your safety and the safety of others, always strive to improve your driving and observation skills.

questions.question: A driver approaching a flashing red traffic signal must:
questions.answerB: Drive carefully without stopping.
questions.answerC: Merge to the right.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and go only when it is safe. At a railroad crossing, a flashing red light indicates that a train is approaching. Yield to the train, and go only when the lights have stopped flashing and all other active warning devices deactivate.

questions.question: To drive safely at night, you should:
questions.answerB: Not drive if you are tired.
questions.answerC: Make sure your headlights are working properly.
questions.explanation: At night, visibility is reduced. Take steps to make driving in the dark more safe for you and the other drivers on the road.

questions.question: Roads with double solid yellow line markings down the center indicate that passing is:
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line down the center of a road indicates that traffic is moving in opposite directions and that passing is not allowed from either direction.

questions.question: A distraction when driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: A distraction when driving is anything that takes your attention away from driving. Driver distractions may occur anytime and anywhere. Distracted driving can cause collisions, resulting in property damage, injury, and death.

questions.question: When making a right turn, you should not:
questions.answerB: Turn too wide for your lane.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: When turning right, you should begin to slow down and activate your turn signal at least 100 feet before making the turn. Be careful not to turn too wide for your lane, as this may interfere with other vehicles.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Change lanes abruptly or spontaneously.
questions.answerC: Check for other vehicles moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you must be sure that there are no vehicles in the space you want to enter. Check for other vehicles behind and to the side of your vehicle by checking your mirrors and blind spots. Always use the proper turn signal before changing lanes to allow surrounding vehicles time to react to your movements.

questions.question: You may avoid the risks of alcohol-related crashes by:
questions.answerA: Deciding before you start drinking that you are not going to drive.
questions.answerB: Simply saying, "No thanks, I'm driving," if someone offers you a drink.
questions.answerC: Calling a taxi.
questions.explanation: The only way to avoid the risks of drinking and driving is to decide before you start drinking that you are not going to drive. Because alcohol affects your judgement, it will be harder for you to make safe decisions after you have started drinking.

questions.question: If you are stopped by a police officer, you should:
questions.answerA: Unbuckle your seat belt and lower your window.
questions.answerB: Get your paperwork ready before the officer reaches your car.
questions.answerC: Stay in your vehicle with your hands on the steering wheel and wait for the officer to approach you.
questions.answerD: Get out of your car and walk toward the patrol car.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped by the police, keep your hands on the wheel and ask any passengers to keep their hands in view as well. You should remain in the vehicle unless the police officer asks you to get out. Wait until the officer asks you to retrieve your driver license, registration, and insurance cards.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Work crew ahead.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that there is an upcoming sharp turn and that they should lower their speed accordingly.

questions.question: When turning left, you should not:
questions.answerB: Cut corners.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: When turning left, you should begin to slow down and activate your turn signal at least 100 feet before making the turn. Be careful not to cut the corner short, as this may interfere with other vehicles.

questions.question: You may park or stop along the shoulder of the freeway:
questions.answerA: As long as you turn on your four-way (emergency) flashers.
questions.answerB: If no part of your vehicle is on the road.
questions.answerC: If you need to look at a map for directions.
questions.answerD: Only if you have an emergency.
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to park on the shoulder of a freeway, except in an emergency.

questions.question: The amount of alcohol in the blood is referred to as:
questions.answerB: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC).
questions.answerC: Rate of alcohol consumption (RAC).
questions.explanation: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a measurement of the percentage of alcohol in the blood. The higher the BAC number, the more impaired a person is.

questions.question: Your tire blows out while you are driving. You should:
questions.answerB: Hold your steering wheel tightly and slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Keep driving normally.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, do not immediately apply the brakes. Grip the steering wheel firmly and steer to remain in your traffic lane. Reduce your speed gradually by releasing the accelerator and staying off the brakes. Once you are moving very slowly, apply the brakes lightly and pull off the road into a safe area.

questions.question: Before returning to your original lane after passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: See both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights.
questions.explanation: When passing is permitted, look for both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Only then may you safely return to your original lane.

questions.question: When you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an approaching emergency vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down until it passes you.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Motion for the emergency vehicle to pass you.
questions.answerD: Merge into the right lane and continue driving.
questions.explanation: Yield the right-of-way to any approaching emergency vehicle that is using its flashing lights or siren, regardless of its direction of travel. You must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, pass through the intersection before coming to a stop on the right side of the road.

questions.question: A good rule to remember for passing is:
questions.answerA: Pass on the right whenever possible.
questions.answerB: Drive with the flow of traffic and pass only as needed.
questions.answerC: Try to get to the front of any slow-moving traffic so that you can see better.
questions.answerD: Always flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your intentions.
questions.explanation: Each time you pass another vehicle, there is an increased chance for a collision. If you are moving faster than surrounding traffic, you will have to continue passing others. Drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit, and pass only as needed.

questions.question: Fatigue increases the risk of:
questions.answerB: Being late for an appointment.
questions.answerC: Falling asleep behind the wheel and crashing.
questions.explanation: Fatigue causes errors related to speed and distance, increases your risk of being in a crash, and causes you to take more time to make decisions. When you are fatigued, you could fall asleep behind the wheel and crash, injuring or killing yourself or others.

questions.question: Always stop before crossing railroad tracks when:
questions.answerA: There isn't room on the other side for you to completely cross the tracks.
questions.answerB: The railroad crossing is located in a city or town that has frequent train traffic.
questions.answerC: You are transporting two or more young children in a passenger vehicle.
questions.explanation: Expect a train on any track, at any time, traveling in either direction. If you need to stop after crossing the tracks, wait until you can completely cross the tracks before proceeding. Make sure your vehicle clears the tracks before you stop.

questions.question: When approaching a stop sign that is not marked by a crosswalk, drivers should stop their vehicles before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: At a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the stop line, if there is one. If there is no stop line, you must make a complete stop before entering the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, you must stop before entering the intersection.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on the road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a series of curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming winding road.

questions.question: When passing on a multilane highway:
questions.answerA: Be sure the passing lane is clear.
questions.answerB: Pass only on the right.
questions.answerC: Watch for oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing, you must make sure the passing lane is clear and give the proper turn signal to show you are going to change lanes.

questions.question: If worried, nervous, angry, or crying, a driver:
questions.answerA: Will drive no differently than they would if they were thinking more clearly.
questions.answerB: Can drive faster because they are more in touch with their senses.
questions.answerC: Should take the time to focus on driving before starting the engine.
questions.answerD: Should call a friend to vent while driving.
questions.explanation: You may not be able to drive well if you are worried, excited, crying, angry, or depressed. Emotions can distract you from your driving because your mind is focused on something else. Take time to calm down and get focused before driving.

questions.question: Many crashes are caused by:
questions.answerA: Drivers traveling too fast for conditions.
questions.answerB: Drivers consistently checking their mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerC: Drivers yielding the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Drivers maintaining a four-second following distance.
questions.explanation: Many crashes are caused by drivers who are driving too fast for conditions. Always drive within the legal speed limits and decrease your speed any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: The effect that alcohol has on your reflexes and judgment:
questions.answerA: Is less pronounced when consuming beer instead of wine.
questions.answerB: Is less pronounced when consuming wine instead of beer.
questions.answerC: Is most pronounced when consuming hard ciders and mixed drinks.
questions.answerD: Depends on the amount of alcohol in your bloodstream.
questions.explanation: Consuming any type of alcohol can have negative effects on your reflexes and judgment. It does not matter which type of alcohol is consumed, only how much alcohol has entered a person's bloodstream.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Low clearance.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be aware of potential traffic entering from an upcoming side road.

questions.question: A solid white line on the right edge of the highway slants in to the left. That shows that:
questions.answerA: There is an intersection just ahead.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a construction area.
questions.answerC: You will be required to turn left just ahead.
questions.explanation: A solid line along the side of the road indicates where its edge is, marking the boundary between the travel lane and the shoulder. If the edge line angles toward the center of the road, this means that the road is narrower ahead.

questions.question: Your first response to reduced visibility should be:
questions.answerB: Reducing your speed.
questions.answerC: Turning on your windshield wipers.
questions.answerD: Looking for road edge markings to guide you.
questions.explanation: Reducing your speed should be your first response to decreased visibility and dangerous road conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: U-turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get out of the car and go for help.
questions.answerB: Lay down in your car and go to sleep.
questions.answerC: Walk into the road and get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerD: Stay in the car, as you are most likely to be found when you stay in your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is stay in your car and wait for help. You are most likely to be found if you don't leave your vehicle. Additionally, it may be unsafe to walk around outside in a snowstorm.

questions.question: What does an orange-colored sign indicate?
questions.answerA: The start of a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: A railroad crossing is ahead.
questions.answerC: A school zone is ahead.
questions.explanation: Construction, maintenance, and emergency operations signs are generally orange with black symbols.

questions.question: If you are following a school bus or tank truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop at all railroad crossings.
questions.explanation: School buses and tank trucks carrying flammable liquids must stop at all railroad crossings. Be prepared to stop at railroad crossings when following one of these vehicles.

questions.question: What is the meaning of this sign?
questions.answerA: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a red light.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal ahead is broken.
questions.answerC: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a green light.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal at the intersection ahead.

questions.question: As you drive, you're required to stop your vehicle:
questions.answerA: At an intersection with a stop sign.
questions.answerB: Where there is a red light.
questions.answerC: When a traffic officer orders you to stop.
questions.explanation: Situations where motorists are required to stop include approaching intersections with stop signs, approaching intersections where a red light is either flashing or illuminated, or any time when a traffic officer orders your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: You may cross solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerB: During daylight hours only.
questions.answerC: At any time.
questions.explanation: As a general rule, broken traffic lines may be crossed but solid lines may not. Solid yellow lines may be crossed only when the driver is making a turn.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: A red and white triangular sign at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white yield sign means that you must decrease speed as you approach an intersection and yield the right-of-way to any vehicles or pedestrians in the intersection. You must be prepared to stop if conditions require it.

questions.question: When you are driving on the freeway and see that a vehicle will be entering your lane from an entrance ramp, you should:
questions.answerB: Honk your horn so they know you are there.
questions.answerC: Ignore them because you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Change lanes to allow them room, if possible.
questions.explanation: Make room for vehicles entering the freeway. Whenever possible, change lanes to allow those entering to do so smoothly and safely.

questions.question: Night driving presents unique problems because:
questions.answerA: The speed limit is increased at night.
questions.answerB: There are fewer cars on the roads at night.
questions.answerC: Distance and vehicle speed are difficult to judge in the dark.
questions.explanation: Night driving creates a unique set of problems for drivers. Due to the reduced visibility, it can be difficult to judge distance and the traveling speeds of other vehicles when driving at night. Drivers can see only as far as their headlights allow.

questions.question: When driving in bad weather, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Increase their speed to reach their final destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Decrease their following distance.
questions.answerC: Increase their following distance.
questions.explanation: When driving on wet roads, drivers should increase their following distance.

questions.question: What does a lane control signal displaying a green arrow above a reversible lane indicate?
questions.answerA: The signal is about to change to a red X.
questions.answerB: Drivers should not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: Drivers may use this lane only to make a left turn.
questions.answerD: Drivers may drive normally in this lane.
questions.explanation: Lane control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. When a lane control signal contains a green arrow, drivers may drive normally in the indicated lane.

questions.question: When approaching a four-way stop, drivers must yield the right-of-way to all motorists who arrived before them.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: At a four-way stop, you must yield the right-of-way to drivers who arrived before you. Wait your turn to enter the intersection.

questions.question: When driving to an unfamiliar area, you:
questions.answerA: Should depend on road signs to find your way.
questions.answerB: Should plan your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Only have to know generally where your destination is.
questions.answerD: Should always choose the most direct route.
questions.explanation: When driving to an unfamiliar area, plan your trip in advance. Don’t start with only a hazy idea of where you are going. If your destination is in an unfamiliar area, check the location on a map before you start to drive.

questions.question: Pedestrians in crosswalks and at intersections always have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Pedestrians have the right-of-way when crossing the road at an intersection. A crosswalk exists anywhere that two streets intersect, whether the crosswalk is marked or unmarked.

questions.question: How do you check your blind spots?
questions.answerA: By looking in your side mirrors.
questions.answerB: By turning your head and looking over your shoulders.
questions.answerC: By looking in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas around your vehicle that you cannot see with your mirrors. Check your blind spots by turning your head and looking over your shoulders.

questions.question: Defensive driving is:
questions.answerA: Identifying dangerous driving situations and taking action to avoid accidents.
questions.answerB: Defending yourself against poor drivers by getting ahead of them in traffic.
questions.answerC: Following the vehicle ahead of you at a close distance.
questions.answerD: Quickly changing lanes and shifting in and out of traffic congestion.
questions.explanation: You drive defensively when you identify dangerous driving situations and take action before an accident occurs. Defensive driving helps prevent conflicts with aggressive, offensive, discourteous, careless, inattentive, impulsive, ignorant, or intoxicated drivers or pedestrians.

questions.question: Drivers may not pass:
questions.answerB: In a no passing zone.
questions.answerC: In the middle of a curve.
questions.explanation: Drivers must not pass in a curve or on a hill. Only pass another vehicle when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you are being followed too closely on a two-lane road:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerB: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the other car.
questions.answerC: Apply your brakes to slow down, then resume your original speed.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed too closely by another driver, merge into a different lane. If there is no lane available for merging, wait until the road ahead is clear and slowly reduce your speed. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing that has no warning signals (such as electric flashing lights or gates), a driver should slow down, look, and listen.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: If a railroad crossing has no warning devices or only a crossbuck sign, you should slow down, look in both directions of the track, and listen for a train or railroad equipment. Only proceed with caution across the tracks when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When passing other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn at least three times.
questions.answerC: Re-enter your lane within 10 feet of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing another vehicle, check your mirrors and blind spots. Before changing lanes, activate the appropriate turn signal. Re-enter the lane when you can see the front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited. Do not make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Only ____ can lower blood alcohol concentration (BAC) and reduce alcohol's effects on a body.
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking alcohol is to allow time for your body to eliminate the alcohol in your system. Nothing you can do, including eating and drinking, can accelerate this process.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive more quickly.
questions.answerC: Drive the speed limit, with caution.
questions.answerD: Not drive more quickly than 20 mph.
questions.explanation: You should slow down at the first sign of rain, snow, or sleet, all of which can create slippery road conditions. When conditions on the road are less than ideal, safety may require that you drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: Just like alcohol and other drugs, drowsiness can:
questions.answerA: Help you to be a better driver.
questions.answerB: Make you feel better.
questions.answerC: Impair your judgment.
questions.explanation: Not getting enough sleep is a cause of poor driving behavior. Just like drugs and alcohol, sleepiness slows reaction time, decreases awareness, and impairs judgment.

questions.question: You should use your horn when:
questions.answerA: Another vehicle is in your way.
questions.answerB: It may help prevent a collision.
questions.answerC: Another driver makes a mistake.
questions.explanation: Only use your horn when it is necessary to avoid collisions. Do not use your horn if a driver or bicyclist is moving slowly and you want him or her to drive faster or get out of your way.

questions.question: When changing lanes on a highway, you should:
questions.answerB: Check your rearview and outside mirrors.
questions.answerC: Check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Any time you want to change lanes, you should properly signal your intentions well in advance, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot. You can check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder in the direction that you plan to move.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not allowed.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal ahead.

questions.question: When turning or changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Always signal your intentions, even when no visible traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Signal only if there is visible traffic.
questions.answerC: Signal only when driving at night.
questions.answerD: Signal only when driving in heavy traffic at night.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions when changing lanes, turning, or pulling away from a curb. Do not allow yourself to become lazy and form the bad habit of not following this law.

questions.question: What might happen when alcohol is combined with another drug?
questions.answerA: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be increased.
questions.answerB: Nothing will happen.
questions.answerC: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be reduced.
questions.answerD: The effects of only the alcohol may be reduced.
questions.explanation: Consuming both alcohol and another drug may enhance the effects of both. For example, taking one drink when you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as if you have had several drinks.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: What can you do to reduce road rage?
questions.answerA: Always signal your intention when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Use your horn frequently.
questions.explanation: To do your part to prevent road rage, you should follow laws, signs, signals, and pavement markings. Always signal your intention when changing lanes.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits drivers from making a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Multiple turns.
questions.answerC: Lane shifting.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential traffic merging from the right. Drivers should prepare to allow the traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Truck exit only.
questions.answerC: Steep downgrade ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a steep downgrade is ahead on the road. Drivers should check their brakes.

questions.question: If driving in fog, a driver should turn on the high beam headlights to increase their field of vision.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: While it is not advisable to drive in fog, if you must drive in foggy conditions, you should drive with the headlights set on dim or use fog lights.

questions.question: When passing a large vehicle, the driver of a small vehicle must be prepared for:
questions.answerB: Excess air pollution.
questions.answerC: Wind gusts produced by the large vehicle.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles can cause wind gusts with a force great enough to cause direction changes in smaller vehicles. Drivers of small vehicles should be prepared to take proper corrective steering action when approaching or passing large vehicles that are moving at or near maximum speeds.

questions.question: While driving at night, a vehicle coming toward you has its high beams on, making it hard for you to see the road ahead. You should:
questions.answerA: Look ahead toward the left edge of your lane.
questions.answerB: Look ahead toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead in your lane.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their high beams, you should avoid looking directly at the headlights. Instead, look toward the right edge of your lane and watch the oncoming vehicle out of the corner of your eye.

questions.question: You exit the freeway on a ramp that curves downhill. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow to a safe speed before the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow to the posted speed limit for the freeway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you have entered the curve to begin braking.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down before entering a curve. You may not be able to see hazards ahead and braking in a curve may cause your vehicle to skid.

questions.question: What color are pavement markings that separate traffic lanes moving in opposite direction?
questions.answerB: White
questions.answerC: Yellow and white
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used in the center of the road to separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: A person walking with a white cane or guide dog is likely to be:
questions.answerB: A person involved with a traffic study.
questions.answerC: A blind person.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian when the pedestrian is a blind person who is using a white cane or guide dog.

questions.question: If you have had several beers, the effects of alcohol will be reduced only by:
questions.answerB: Waiting several hours.
questions.answerC: Drinking several cups of coffee.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the impairing effects of alcohol is to give the body time to remove it from the body. Drinking coffee, physical activity, or taking a cold shower will not speed up this process. It takes about one hour to cancel the effects of one drink.

questions.question: If two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time:
questions.answerA: The largest vehicle has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car on the left shall yield to the car on the right.
questions.answerD: The car on the right shall yield to the car on the left.
questions.explanation: If two vehicles arrive at the same time to an uncontrolled intersection, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right. The driver on the left may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: At a school crossing sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop, whether there is a stop sign or not.
questions.answerB: Watch for children and be ready to stop.
questions.answerC: Always sound your horn when you see children.
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs mean you are approaching a school zone and/or school crossing. When you see these signs, be alert and prepare to stop.

questions.question: You may pass a vehicle when:
questions.answerA: You are on a hill or curve.
questions.answerB: You are on a road with a solid line next to your lane.
questions.answerC: You are on a road with a broken line next to your lane.
questions.explanation: A single broken line indicates that drivers may cross from either lane to change lanes. Dashed yellow lines alongside solid yellow lines indicate that passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken line, but not from the lane next to the solid line. Only change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you drive more slowly than the flow of traffic, you will most likely:
questions.answerA: Interfere with traffic and receive a ticket.
questions.answerB: Improve traffic flow.
questions.answerC: Demonstrate defensive driving techniques.
questions.explanation: You must drive more slowly than usual when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. However, if you block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic by driving too slowly, you may be cited. You should match the speed of traffic, unless the speed of traffic exceeds the legal speed limit.

questions.question: Vehicles stopped behind a school bus with its red lights flashing must remain stopped until:
questions.answerA: All students are off the bus.
questions.answerB: The stop arm is retracted.
questions.answerC: The stop arm is retracted and the bus resumes motion.
questions.explanation: When a school bus is flashing its red lights and has its stop arm extended, motorists must come to a full stop until the lights are turned off, the stop arm is withdrawn, and the bus begins moving again.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: You must bear either right or left.
questions.answerC: A four-way intersection is ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a Y intersection ahead. You must bear either to the right or to the left.

questions.question: You should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead when you:
questions.answerA: Are following a small passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are being tailgated by another driver.
questions.answerC: Are driving more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When being tailgated, create extra space in front of your vehicle and do not brake suddenly. Slow down gradually or merge into another lane to prevent a collision with the tailgater.

questions.question: When parking uphill next to a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Keep the rear tires against the curb.
questions.answerB: Keep the front tires straight ahead.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel away from the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn your steering wheel toward the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking facing uphill on a street that has a curb, set your parking brake and turn your steering wheel away from the curb. This way, if your vehicle starts to roll, it will roll into the curb.

questions.question: If you’re going to turn left onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into:
questions.answerB: The lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerC: Either lane.
questions.explanation: You should always turn from the lane that is closest to the direction you want to go. Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.

questions.question: This is the shape and color of a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs mean drivers must yield. When approaching a yield sign, slow down to a speed that is reasonable for existing conditions and stop if necessary. If you must stop, do so at a marked stop line, if it exists.

questions.question: Which of the following does not happen after drinking?
questions.answerA: Your reflexes and reaction time slow down.
questions.answerB: Your judgement of speed and distance is distorted.
questions.answerC: You are less alert.
questions.answerD: You calm down and can concentrate better.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces your reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, changes your judgment of speed and distances, reduces your ability to recover from the glare of headlights, and often reduces your inhibitions and makes you more likely to take risks.

questions.question: When may you pass on the right shoulder of the road?
questions.answerB: When the car in front of you is driving too slowly.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is turning.
questions.explanation: If you pass on the right, do so only when conditions permit you to pass legally and safely. Under no circumstances are you allowed to drive off the pavement or onto the shoulder to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: Which lane must you be in before making a left turn from a one-way street?
questions.answerA: The lane nearest the left curb.
questions.answerB: The lane nearest the center of the street.
questions.answerC: The lane nearest the right curb.
questions.explanation: When making any turn, turn from the lane closest to the direction you wish to travel into the first available legal lane. If you are making a left turn from a one-way street, this means that you would make the turn from the lane nearest to the left curb.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: What can you do to avoid the need to make emergency stops while driving in traffic?
questions.answerA: Honk your horn to make others aware of your presence.
questions.answerB: Look ahead and maintain a safe following distance.
questions.answerC: Drive in the right lane only.
questions.answerD: Drive more slowly than the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Keeping a safe following distance will enable you to react to an upcoming problem without the need for a emergency stop, which could cause a driver behind you to crash into the back of your vehicle.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should:
questions.answerB: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more hazardous than daytime driving because the lowered visibility makes it difficult to judge speed, distances, and other potential hazards. Increase your following distance to help prevent a potential collision if the vehicle in front of you should stop abruptly. Use your headlights when driving at night, following the rules for proper usage of high beams and low beams.

questions.question: It is necessary to use your low beams any time you are:
questions.answerB: On a freeway.
questions.answerC: In fog.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Left turn signal.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that parking is not permitted.

questions.question: You want to park downhill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which way do you turn your front wheels?
questions.answerB: Right, toward the side of the road
questions.answerC: Left, toward the center of the road
questions.explanation: When parking facing downhill on a road with or without a curb, or when facing uphill on a road without a curb, turn your front wheels toward the edge of the road so your vehicle will roll away from traffic if the brakes fail. However, when parking uphill on a road with a curb, turn your wheels toward the center of the road so the vehicle will roll into the curb if the brakes fail.

questions.question: What does a lane control signal displaying a steady yellow X above a reversible lane indicate?
questions.answerA: The signal is about to change to a red X.
questions.answerB: The signal is about to change to a green arrow.
questions.answerC: Drivers may drive normally in this lane.
questions.answerD: Drivers may drive slowly in this lane.
questions.explanation: Lane control signals are used when the direction of the flow of traffic in a specific lane changes throughout the day. They are used to show which lanes of traffic are open and closed, as well as to show if toll booths are open or closed. When a lane control signal contains a steady yellow X, drivers should clear the indicated lane because the lane signal is about to change to a red X.

questions.question: A red arrow displayed on a traffic light means that:
questions.answerA: A driver must proceed slowly through the intersection.
questions.answerB: A driver must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.
questions.answerC: A driver must stop and then proceed when the signal changes to a green light or green arrow.
questions.answerD: A driver may turn in the direction that the red arrow is pointing.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign indicates otherwise, a traffic signal displaying a red arrow means that drivers must come to a full stop and remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears.

questions.question: Worn or bald tires:
questions.answerB: Are likely to hydroplane.
questions.answerC: Can increase your stopping distance.
questions.explanation: Worn or bald tires can increase your stopping distance and make turning more difficult. Tires without adequate tread also increase the risk of hydroplaning.

questions.question: When in a travel lane on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You may stop to drop off passengers.
questions.answerB: You may stop to look up an address.
questions.answerC: You may make a U-turn or back up if you get on the wrong entrance ramp of the freeway.
questions.answerD: Don’t stop for any reason. Keep moving until you can safely pull off the road.
questions.explanation: You should not stop in a travel lane for any reason. Instead, keep moving until you can safely pull off of the road. If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up. Go to the next turn or exit or where you can safely turn around.

questions.question: This is a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: This triangular sign is a "Yield" sign. When you see this sign, you must slow down to check for traffic and yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and approaching cross traffic. Stop only if it is necessary to do so.

questions.question: When faced with an oncoming car to the left and a bicyclist to the right, you should:
questions.answerB: Split the difference.
questions.answerC: Let the car pass and then pass the bike.
questions.explanation: When there is more than one potential hazard on the road, you should ensure that you only have to deal with one of them at a time. For example, when there is a bicyclist on the right that you want to pass and an oncoming car to the left, you should not try to squeeze between both at the same time. Instead, let the oncoming car pass, and then pass the bicyclist.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of of an approaching traffic signal.

questions.question: Sudden wind gusts on highways:
questions.answerA: Generally affect only the movement of large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Only cause visibility problems.
questions.answerC: Can cause problems for all vehicles.
questions.explanation: While it can create special problems for large vehicles, strong wind can cause problems for all drivers. Wind can lower visibility by blowing dirt and dust into the roadway, but it can sometimes also physically move a vehicle.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerB: Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move.
questions.answerC: Rely on the left side mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, glance over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot. You may need to look several times before changing lanes. You must keep track of what traffic is doing in front of you as well as what traffic is doing in the lane next to you.

questions.question: You are waiting in the intersection to complete a left turn. You should:
questions.answerA: Signal and keep your wheels turned to the left.
questions.answerB: Signal and keep your wheels straight.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights so drivers will let you through.
questions.answerD: Drive around the rear of a car if it blocks you.
questions.explanation: You must always signal before turning or changing lanes. You should keep your wheels straight while waiting to make a left turn. If another vehicle hits you from behind, this ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in school zones is:
questions.answerB: 35 mph.
questions.answerC: 25 mph.
questions.explanation: In a school zone, the speed limit is 25 miles per hour. If a different speed limit is posted, follow the posted speed limit.

questions.question: Who is required to wear a seat belt?
questions.answerB: Front seat passengers
questions.answerC: Children under age 13
questions.explanation: Oklahoma's seat belt law requires every front seat occupant to wear a seat belt. Occupants under the age of 13 must be fastened into their seat belts, regardless of their seating position.

questions.question: Only vehicles displaying special plates or parking placards for persons with disabilities may park in spaces reserved for them by an official sign.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: A parking space marked by a "Reserved Parking for Persons with Disabilities" sign may only be used by vehicles that display Persons with Disabilities license plates, Disabled Veteran license plates, and/or disabled parking placards.

questions.question: As you enter into a roundabout, you should slow down and:
questions.answerA: Yield to any crossing pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.answerB: Yield to any car already within the roundabout.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: When entering a roundabout, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and traffic already in the roundabout.

questions.question: Drowsy drivers:
questions.answerA: Should drink strong black coffee to stay awake.
questions.answerB: Can drive so poorly that they may appear to be drunk.
questions.answerC: Can stay alert by opening a window and turning up the radio.
questions.explanation: Drowsiness can make people drive so poorly that they appear to be drunk. Opening a window, turning on the radio, or drinking coffee is not enough to make a drowsy driver alert to roadway hazards.

questions.question: You may leave the scene of a collision if you don't think it looks bad.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Don’t ever leave the scene of a collision before taking the proper steps. If you leave, you may be prosecuted for a “hit and run.”

questions.question: Drinking coffee after drinking alcohol:
questions.answerB: Cancels the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Has no effect on blood alcohol concentration.
questions.explanation: Drinking coffee will not reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC). While it may help you to stay awake, it cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerB: Wave your arms.
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: To avoid glare from the headlights of an approaching car:
questions.answerA: Look briefly toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stay focused on the centerline on the road.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams.
questions.explanation: You should avoid looking toward the bright lights of an oncoming vehicle by glancing toward the right side of the road. After looking briefly toward the side of the road, continue looking ahead to check on the position of the other vehicle.

questions.question: You are driving up a hill and are approaching a heavy truck from the rear. You should know that:
questions.answerA: The truck may be traveling at a speed slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: You may not be able to safely pass the truck.
questions.answerC: You may not be able to legally pass the truck.
questions.explanation: Drivers must be aware that large vehicles often travel at a speed slower than the posted speed limit, especially when driving on an incline, and should use caution when approaching a large vehicle from the rear. When on a hill with limited visibility, it is unlawful to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: When may you legally drive around or under a railroad crossing gate?
questions.answerB: When you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.answerC: When the warning lights are not flashing.
questions.explanation: Do not go around or under any lowered gate at a railroad crossing. Once the gate is raised, do not proceed across the tracks until you can see clearly in both directions and are sure there are no trains coming.

questions.question: If you approach a flashing red traffic light, you:
questions.answerA: Are traveling in the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: Must treat the intersection as if it is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: May not proceed until it changes to green.
questions.explanation: Treat a flashing red light the same as a stop sign. Come to a complete stop at the stop line or, if there is no stop line, prior to the crosswalk and before entering the intersection. Yield to all other traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: You may be able to identify an aggressive driver by:
questions.answerA: Their erratic and improper lane changes.
questions.answerB: The number of passengers in their car.
questions.answerC: Their tendency to drive slowly.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should remain aware of the actions of surrounding drivers. If you notice an aggressive driver nearby making erratic or improper lane changes, you should not challenge them. The safest way to handle an aggressive driver is to get out of their way.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching the end of a divided highway.
questions.answerB: You are approaching the beginning of a divided highway.
questions.answerC: The road will be slippery ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. Keep to the right of the median divider.

questions.question: If your vehicle has a two-part safety belt system, you should:
questions.answerB: Use both the lap and shoulder belts.
questions.answerC: Use only the shoulder belt.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has a two-part seat belt system, be sure to wear both the lap belt and the shoulder belt. Wearing either part alone greatly reduces your protection. If you have an automatic shoulder belt, be sure to buckle your lap belt as well.

questions.question: When stopping on snow or ice, drivers who are operating vehicles equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should:
questions.answerB: Press and hold the brake pedal firmly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes and wait for the car to drift to a stop.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), a driver should press the brake pedal firmly when stopping on a snowy or icy surface. The ABS will pump the brakes more rapidly than a driver would be able to.

questions.question: When approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and/or flashing lights, a driver must immediately:
questions.answerA: Pull to the right and stop.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right and slow down.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and turn on their vehicle's four-way flashers.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the emergency vehicle pass.
questions.explanation: When you are approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its lights, sirens, and/or other warning devices, you must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No outlet.
questions.answerC: No U-turns.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited. You may see a sign like this at an intersection that commonly has oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Driving is a right, not a privilege.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Your opportunity to operate a motor vehicle on Oklahoma’s streets and highways is a privilege granted by the state under certain conditions. This privilege is granted only to people who can show that they have the knowledge and ability to safely operate their vehicles. Abuse of this privilege may result in the loss of your driver license.

questions.question: A motorist making a left turn at an intersection must yield the right-of-way to a bicyclist entering the intersection from the opposite direction.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, you must yield to oncoming bicycles in the same manner that you would yield to oncoming motor vehicles. Keep your wheels straight while waiting to turn and proceed when the way is clear of traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: Before changing lanes on a multilane highway, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn on your headlights.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should look in your rearview and side mirrors to make sure no one is trying to pass you. You should also look over your shoulder to make sure that no one is in your blind spot.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerB: Trucks use second gear
questions.answerC: Steep hill
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that you are approaching a steep hill. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.
